pullRequest.title: doc: clarify Java requirements
pullRequest.bodyText:
Clarify what versions of Java are required for older JMRI releases and what versions of Java will be considered supported under the Oracle LTS/non-LTS release cadence.
Depending on the operating system JMRI 4.2 or older may work with Java versions newer that 8, but these all definitely break on macOS with Java 11, may break on other operating systems with Java 11, and since there is no point in running these older versions if Java 11 can be used, I just capped the supported version for 4.2 or older at Java 8.

nodes.bodyText: I think the Java version discussion is fine.  I'm not sure about saying that fully supported "means that problems found will be fixed or addressed in other means"; we don't always do that.  Could we change that last sentence to focus on something like "If you encounter a problem while using a Java version that is considered 'best-effort' by JMRI, people may not be able to fix any problems you encounter unless you install a fully-supported Java version" or something like that?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -67,15 +67,31 @@
  • Version 2.12 can run on any computer system that will - run Java 1.5 or later.
    • + run Java 1.5 through Java 8 (also known as Java 1.8). -
  • Version 2.14.1 requires Java 1.5 (or 1.6 if you wish - for drag & drop)
    • +
  • Version 2.14.1 requires Java 1.5 (or Java 1.6 to support + for drag & drop) through Java 8.
    • -
  • Version 3.10.1 requires Java 1.7 or later.
    • +
  • Version 3.10.1 requires Java 1.7 through Java 8.
    • -
  • Version 4.2 requires Java 1.8.
    • -
+
  • Version 4.2 requires Java 8.
    • + + +

    As of JMRI 4.20, JMRI is only fully supported when running on the most + current update possible to the two most recent Java Long Term Support + (LTS) releases (8 or 11 as of July 2020) and will receive "best effort" + support on the latest Java release (14 as of July 2020). In this context, + "fully supported" means that problems found will be fixed or addressed in + other means; "best effort" means that fixes to run on the latest Java + release that do not break compatibility with the oldest supported LTS + release will be considered.

commit.message: doc: do not make an unkeepable promise
